awd_titl_txt: Characterizing and assessing number sense in third through eighth grade students
awd_abstract_narration:
One goal of mathematics curricular and instructional reforms in the United States is to help students build “mature number sense,” which involves making sense of numbers and operations, using reasoning to notice patterns, and flexibly selecting the most effective and efficient problem-solving strategies. In support of this goal, mathematics educators have developed a variety of instructional practices designed to move students beyond seeing mathematics as a set of disconnected procedures and facts to appreciating it as a coherent set of ideas and tools. These practices have been growing in popularity across mathematics classrooms, but it is unclear if students’ mature number sense is improving. One reason for slow progress is that the field currently lacks a rigorously validated measure of mature number sense that is both widely accepted and easy to use. Moreover, even though mathematics educators generally agree on the importance of mature number sense, there is little evidence demonstrating that it is a measurably distinct characteristic of mathematical cognition. Lack of such knowledge is a critical problem because, without it, researchers cannot explain, predict, and study mature number sense, and teachers are left to rely on their own intuitions about whether and how to focus on it in their classrooms. In this project, researchers will advance fundamental knowledge of mathematical cognition through the development of innovative metrics and methods to assess mature number sense with valid and reliable scores for use with students in grades 3-8. 

The central hypothesis is that mature number sense is a measurable characteristic of mathematical cognition, separable from both domain-specific knowledge (e.g., arithmetic fluency, fraction knowledge) and domain-general constructs (e.g., creativity, cognitive flexibility), that predicts math-related beliefs and achievement. The research team will work with a diverse sample of students in grades 3-8 to refine, extend, and validate a brief assessment of mature number sense. They will start with a measure that they iteratively developed and validated in a large pilot study with middle and high school students, and they will optimize it as the “middle school form” (for grades 6-8). They will collect additional evidence of validity for this form by comparing it to other, more lengthy measures of mature number sense and by conducting a longitudinal study to examine if scores on the measure in fall predict grade-level mathematics learning and math-related beliefs in spring. Next, they will extend the measure downward to include upper elementary grades 3-5. Items will be iteratively developed and examined for construct relevance using expert ratings, classical and IRT item statistics, and retrospective think-aloud strategy reports of students during problem solving. The researchers will examine if the factor structure of the elementary form is the same as that found with the middle school form, testing measurement invariance across the two grade-level groupings. They also will develop a technical manual for researchers and teachers. By the end of the project, there will be a practical, validated assessment of mature number sense for students in grades 3-8 that is easy to administer in schools, after-school programs, research laboratories, and homes. The target audiences for this measure include basic researchers interested in studying mathematical cognition, intervention researchers interested in studying the effects of innovative instructional practices on students’ number sense, and teachers who wish to monitor their students’ progress toward the “processes and proficiencies” with longstanding importance in mathematics education.

This project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances fundamental research on STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

por.por_cntn:
In the late 1980s, "number sense" emerged as a key goal in U.S. mathematics education. It was featured in federal reports (e.g., National Research Council, 1989) and national curriculum frameworks (e.g., NCTM, 1989), highlighting its importance as a core objective for K-12 students. Students exhibiting this disposition make sense of numerical situations and use a conceptual understanding of number and operations to flexibly solve problems (McIntosh et al., 1997). Some researchers (e.g., Whitacre et al., 2020) refer to this construct as "mature number sense" to differentiate it from other related constructs, such as the approximate number system and early numeracy. Despite being a key goal for over 40 years, it remains unclear if students' mature number sense is improving. Teachers generally agree on the importance of mature number sense, but there is little evidence on how it relates to general mathematics achievement or if it is even a unique construct that is measurably distinct from overall achievement. One reason for this lack of progress is the absence of a practical measure of mature number sense with strong validity evidence (e.g., AERA et al., 2014).

In this project, researchers at the University of Notre Dame developed a practical, brief assessment of mature number sense for middle school students (grades 6-8) and extended it downward to late elementary students (grades 3-5). Guided by the Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing (e.g., AERA et al., 2014), they gathered validity evidence for the interpretation of student scores from test content, response processes, internal structure, and relation to other variables. Additionally, they conducted longitudinal studies to determine if mature number sense uniquely predicts students' grade-level mathematics achievement over a school year.

In consultation with prior research, expert mathematics teachers, teacher educators, cognitive scientists, and mathematics education researchers, the team specified a four-component framework of mature number sense: (1) understanding basic number concepts and number magnitude, (2) using multiple representations of a number, (3) understanding the effect of arithmetic operations on numbers, and (4) understanding mathematical equivalence. They expected mature number sense to be an overarching hierarchical latent construct with these four components each theoretically related to it. And indeed, a bifactor model with each component as a specific factor best fit the response data. During item development, the research team gathered evidence using expert item review, as well as evidence of student response processes using a retrospective think-aloud protocol where students solved problems and then were immediately asked to explain how they solved the problem. Findings suggest that students are overwhelmingly using number sense when solving items on the assessment correctly. Wide-scale field test administrations showed internal consistency and high test-retest reliability.

To gather evidence on the relation with other variables, researchers compared student scores on the brief assessment of mature number sense with their performance on two other well-developed but time-intensive measures of number sense: the Three-Tier Number Sense Test (Yang, 2019) and an in-depth, one-on-one interview (e.g., Markovits & Sowder, 1994). Student scores on the brief assessment correlated highly with both other measures, even when controlling for fluency in solving single-digit arithmetic problems. These findings suggest that the brief, multiple-choice assessment measures the same construct as longer, more labor-intensive assessments.

In two longitudinal studies, one with middle school students and one with late elementary students, researchers found consistent evidence that mature number sense is distinct from several domain-general and math-specific constructs, including verbal fluency, executive function, cognitive reflection, adaptive math-related beliefs, fluency in single-digit arithmetic, and fraction/decimal computation. That is, exhibiting strong number sense is not the same as "executive functioning" or being "good at school math." Cross-sectional analyses indicated that mature number sense at the beginning of the school year is the strongest predictor of mathematics achievement at the same timepoint. Most importantly, mature number sense at the beginning of the year in grades 4-8 was the strongest unique predictor of end-of-year mathematics achievement, controlling for beginning-of-year achievement.

All in all, this project significantly advanced understanding of the nomological network involving mature number sense and its related constructs. It also produced a practical assessment for grades 3-8 that is easy to administer in schools, afterschool programs, and research labs. This assessment will be freely available to classroom teachers for monitoring students' mature number sense and researchers interested in conducting further studies. Results have been disseminated through conference presentations, invited lectures, peer-reviewed publications, professional development sessions for teachers, local community events, and a tri-annual newsletter showcasing recent research in cognitive science. The project integrated research with teaching and public service, forging productive partnerships among the PI and co-PIs' labs and community partners. It also provided teaching and mentoring opportunities for a diverse group of undergraduates, postbaccalaureate research associates, graduate students, research staff, and postdoctoral scholars, and it produced rich datasets for future research on students' mature number sense from grades 3-8.
